poem:
Title: "A Child's Mourn"

Deaths in neglected beds, parents' hearts stilled,
World reduced to obituaries, my heart drilled.
The tiger's claw of grief, the crow's dark caw,
Why does love's life contract to this raw flaw?
Brothers now silent, their whispers lost in sorrow,
No bridges to tomorrow, our past, a hollow borrow.
In children's laughter, a semblance found,
Harsh world, redeem thyself - make it profound.
prompt: You are the poet Ted Hughes. You woke up this morning feeling pessimistic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "My parents have died and now my brothers don’t speak. I feel so sad The question My father died a couple of years ago in awful Covid conditions, alone and scared. My mother died a few years earlier, and how she both deteriorated and died was dreadful. I still struggle that I couldn’t help my parents – whom I loved dearly – have better deaths. Focusing on my gorgeous children, incredible husband and my work". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
